notesStmt.note: Some marginal glosses relating to subjects of adjacent passages, in an early hand
De Ricci, Seymour, with the assistance of W. J. Wilson, Census of Medieval and Renaissance Manuscripts in the United States and Canada, vol. 2 (New York,: H. W. Wilson, 1935-40), p. 2049, no. 133.

Free Library of Philadelphia, A Descriptive Catalogue of the John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts in the Free Library of Philadelphia, compiled by Edwin Wolf, 2nd, with an introduction by Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach (Philadelphia: The Free Library, 1937), p. 216, no. 197.

msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This late fifteenth century manuscript, likely produced in Florence, contains the text of Thomas de Waleys's commentary on Saint Augustine's De civitate dei (City of God). Waleys was a Dominican, likely from Wales, who was educated at Oxford and Paris and was active in the first half of the fourteenth century.

msItem.title: Expositio in civitatem dei S. Augustini (Commentary on St. Augustine's City of god)
msItem.author: Waleys, Thomas, approximately 1287-1350?

msItem.title: Expositio in Civitatem Dei S. Augustini
msItem.explicit: ...ad quam nos producat qui vivit et regnat per omniasecula seculorum. Amen. Deo gratias amen." [fol. 115v]

msItem.title: Index of notable histories
msItem.incipit: Notabilis ystoria de captione urbis per gothos in prologo [fol. 121v]

msItem.title: Print catalog clipping, W.C. Bull & Auvache, London

supportDesc.extent: i+122; 304 x 217 mm bound to 315 x 226 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto; modern pagination in pencil, upper left recto; early pagination in ink, partially cropped, upper right recto and upper left verso

p.catchwords: Downward-facing catchwords in lower right corner at fols. 10v, 20v, and 30v; horizontal catchwords in center of lower margin at fols. 40v, 48v, 56v, 64v, 72v, 80v, 88v, 96v, 104v, and 112v

layoutDesc.layout: Two columns of forty-three lines, ruled in plummet; running book numbers in red ink, center of upper margin; written area: 223 x 152 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: One large initial on the first page in gold and colors of a Florentine type in the manner of Antonio de Chierico, with foliate decoration and extensions containing gold dots, a coat-of-arms in the lower margin supported by two putti with the partially erased monogram IG in the center of the arms; twenty-two smaller initials in gold on grounds of red, green and blue; capitals and paragraph marks in red and blue; rubrication, headings, and underlining in red
Inside front coverBookplate, John Frederick Lewis
1rCoat-of-arms supported by two putti with the partially erased monogram IG in the center of the arms
1rIlluminated initial F with foliate decoration and extensions

binding.p: French eighteenth-century red morocco, gilt back and edges, in slipcase

history.provenance: Bought in Florence, Aug. 8, 1486, by a Franciscan monk, Frater Salvator Orlandini de Lanciolina, according to ownership inscription on fol. 122r ("Iste liber expositionis super librum Augustini De civitate dei est as usum fratris Salvatoris Orlandini de Lanciolina ordinis minoribus quem emit Florentie optimo partio anno 1486 die 8 augusti"); R. Dugate (?) circa 1880; Bull and Auvache, London (print catalog clipping on lower pastedown); sold to John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia; given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936
